top_comment.text:
My little brother round a baby grass snake(or garter snake cant remember 
which) and decided to keep it. Its growing really fast and we have no clue 
what to feed it or how to care for it. Any tips?﻿
top_comment.author: Silentfinger

comments.text: +Sammi Palmer thanks a lot. I'll let him know
comments.author: Silentfinger

comments.text:
Snakes need to live in a tank usually called a vivarium, which should be 
big enough for the snake to easily move around in. On the bottom of the 
tank you can put newspaper or aspen shreddings. The snake will need a water 
bowl for bathing in (this helps when they're shedding and to keep them 
clean) and at least one hide. Snakes normally need to be fed every 
two-three days, with a dead mouse about as wide as the widest part of the 
snakes head (they are normally sold frozen, but make sure you defrost it 
first!). Its usually recommended to feed the snake in a tank separate to 
its home, and offer the mouse head first on tweezers. Stressy snakes may 
regurgitate their food, so leave them in the tank for about half an hour to 
allow digestion, and keep handling brief until it's had time to settle. 
Grass snakes dont really need much in the way of extra heat, but you should 
keep the snake in a warm room away from any vibrations that could stress it 
out; such as the TV or Radio.
A quick google search should give you any more info you need. Hope that 
helps :)
comments.author: Sammi Palmer

top_comment.text:
I have a question that I would love answered! My leopard gecko has recently 
begun refusing to eat, and I can't seem to convince him to do so. He's fed 
on a diet composed mainly of mealworms, because he won't eat crickets (and 
I find crickets incessantly annoying). This has happened before, and I've 
had to force feed him. I don't really want to do that again. He is 
defecating, so I'm sure that he isn't impacted. What can I do?﻿
top_comment.author: Danielle

comments.text:
I also just ordered Phoenix Worms from a Canadian company. They say that 
they're good for animals that don't regularly feed, and that they're high 
in calcium! Hopefully those will get him to eat, and I can use them and the 
mealworms as feeder food, rather than just one. As I previously said, if he 
refuses those as well, he will be going to see a vet.
comments.author: Danielle

comments.text:
He's been refusing food for about a week now. I believe it started right 
after he shed, which is normal, because he typically does that. That 
behaviour usually only lasts for a few days though, and it's been much 
loner than that. His last meal was about four mealworms, and I haven't 
changed anything in his environment at all. I sprinkle calcium on his 
worms, and he is a boy. I want to try wax worms, but they're fairly 
unavailable in my area.  I might just have to ship some in to kickstart his 
appetite. His tail is quite large, so I'm not worried about him going 
hungry, I just don't know why he won't eat. His temperature is about 85 
degrees Fahrenheit on his warm side, and 30 on his cold side. That's been 
working since I got him. If this continues, and I can't kickstart his 
appetite, I will take him to the vet. Thank you!
comments.author: Danielle

comments.text:
Temperature, calcium, and stress are the main causes that they might not 
eat. Shedding and being gravid (if it's a female of course!) will also 
affect their eating patterns. You can also try a small cockroach to see if 
that will entice his predator drive to kick in. Wax worms are a juicy 
treat, maybe he's just being picky. How large is his fat reserves in his 
tail? If he doesn't start eating in a few days after you've checked all his 
necessary environmental level are correct, an exam by your vet is needed. 
Force feeding is very stressful for the gecko and for you.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text:
How long has he been refusing food? Some geckos go off their food for a few 
days before they shed. How long has it been and how large was his last 
meal? Have you changed his supplements at all, or the temperature?
comments.author: Sammi Palmer

top_comment.text: Is it possible to get a pet fox like what you guys have?﻿
top_comment.author: LegoCookieDoggie

comments.text:
Their fox isn't a pet.  All their animals are for education purposes or 
have been rescued from being a pet.  They go to schools to educate kids 
about why a fox shouldn't be a pet.  Think mobile zoo rather than house 
full of pets.
comments.author: Philc1v6

comments.text:
Foxes dont reallly make good pets. They are very messy and much more 
difficult to train than normal dogs. They can also be aggressive, and their 
requirements are more difficult to provide for; you'd have to build a large 
den in your garden; they cant live exclusively indoors, but if you let them 
out they have the agility to leap or climb over pretty tall fences. I 
worked at a fox rescue for a while, and fostered a group of fox cubs for a 
month or two in order to re-release them into the wild. They're more 
difficult to care for than you'd expect. If you want to care for foxes, see 
if theres a rescue near you that might have a foster programme.
comments.author: Sammi Palmer

top_comment.text:
My cat has problems taking his 1 a day pill. Any way I can make it easier 
on both of us? ﻿
top_comment.author: April Genet

comments.text: Oh good idea about the olive oil
comments.author: April Genet

comments.text:
I agree with +Sammi Palmer , you should try to put it as far to the back of 
the throat as possible but mind your nails, since big nails can easily hurt 
them! I usually dip the pill in olive oil so it slips more easily as well.
comments.author: Madalena Vilar

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply! He holds his breath so it hard to get him to swallow. 
Will ask about the crushing up. :]
comments.author: April Genet

comments.text:
Cats are notoriously difficult to give tablets to. The best way is usually 
to offer the tablet hidden inside a treat like a piece of chicken. To 
manually tablet a difficult cat, restrain him/her then put the tablet as 
far to the back of the throat as possible and hold the mouth closed. 
Rubbing the throat can encourage swallowing. You can also ask your vet if 
its possible to give the tablet in ground-up form, mixed into one of the 
cats meals; its not suitable for all tablet types, but it can work quite 
well.
comments.author: Sammi Palmer

top_comment.text:
Oh I have a question, why does my cat scratch at the windows when there is 
absolutely nothing out there, and how do I get her to stop? Okay that was 2 
questions. She was born in 2005, and she has done this her whole life. I've 
watched her. I never see anything outside that she might want to get at... 
so I don't understand. I just wish she wouldn't do it so much. :/﻿
top_comment.author: Dara Perih

comments.text:
She might do it because she likes the way it feels or has an urge like with 
a scratching post.  My cat does it too sometimes and she has a couple of 
scratching posts she uses.  I try to keep her nails trimmed and I think 
that helps.
comments.author: J Dyer

comments.text: Probably her reflection?
comments.author: Sammi Palmer

comments.text:
My cat does that, but he's an indoor/outdoor cat and he does it when he 
wants to go outside. If you can you could take your cat outside for a bit 
when he does it, even supervised, just to give her a change of scenery
comments.author: Alec Wilder

comments.text:
My cat does this too... I keep thinking he wants to go outside, so I'll 
open up the sliding glass door and he'll stare at me like "What?" Then I'll 
close it and he'll repeat it 5 minutes later.
comments.author: Artemis Brown

comments.text:
it might be seeing its reflection or maybe it dose not have any stimulation 
for its claws like a scratch post, maybe spray water and vinegar on window 
or some thing else it does not like the smell of to turn it off that area
comments.author: Belv

top_comment.text:
Here's a question, and I swear I'm just curious: why is chopping the 
vegetables so important that you have to devote so much time to it? The 
animals don't get their food chopped for them in the wild, so why not just 
give it to them whole or in larger chunks that are easier to chop?﻿
top_comment.author: Serena Castells

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana So do you measure everything by volume then? You 
were talking about a cup full of broccoli, so why not simply weigh out what 
that cup is, and do it by weight instead?
comments.author: Sam Blair

comments.text: +AnimalWonders Montana Thanks for answering!
comments.author: Serena Castells

comments.text:
+Dave Kay
 It might simply be preference and speed. I work in a bakery and often 
times I have to slice hundreds of buns. It's faster to work with a regular 
bread knife than worry about an electrical one, and I have more control 
over where and what I cut. You also have more of a feel of where the blade 
actually is. As far as food processor, I feel like that's more of a mini 
blender substitute, rather than a chopping item. Good for dicing, but not 
much else.
comments.author: Brett Harris

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana I presume there are reasons that something like a 
food processor or whatever isn't viable? Perhaps inconsistent chunk size, 
or too much 'dust', or something?
comments.author: Dave Kay

comments.text:
We give the animals a wide variety of veggies and the easiest way to 
provide that is to have a mixture that we can efficiently measure out into 
specific amounts: 5g, 10g, 1tbs, 1/3cup, etc. If the pieces were larger, 
small animals would only get one type of veggie (like one big chunk of 
carrot instead of  smaller pieces of carrot, broccoli, yam, cabbage, beet, 
and cauliflower. Also, like +Selestrielle was getting at, accurately 
measuring a cup of larger broccoli florets is a lot more difficult than a 
bunch of small chopped cubes and crumbs :)
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text:
The huge veggies we get aren't sized for natural/wild growth. Carrots, for 
example, would've been pinkie finger sized before humans selectively bred 
them to be... Child's forearm size.
comments.author: Zoe Rickard

comments.text:
Maybe it's easier to control portion size with veggies cut in smaller 
pieces.
comments.author: Selestrielle

captions.text:
Since we're launching on this new awesomeness
of videos, I feel like I should get a few
things off my chest.

#1, I am crazy about animals, as in I'm crazy
driven to provide them awesome care, even
if they're not my own.

#2, Animals are really, really, really messy,
and it's really hard to keep them clean and
happy.

#3, I log everything. Like, seriously, everything;
I'm walking along, going about my business

and I'm like, "Oh, hey, it's 10:30," I'm like,
"Hey, it's snowing; better write it down."

"Oh, so-and-so pooped; better write it down."
Yeah, I log everything. It's crazy.

#4, I can chop veggies like nobody's mother.
Wanna race?

#5, There's never an instance when you cannot
learn something more about something; nobody

knows everything. Well... wait, maybe somebody
does know everything there is currently available

to know about something, but that doesn't
mean there isn't something more to discover.
[Intro]

Okay, so I think most children come into this
world with a natural curiosity about nature

and animals, and western society just inundates
them with a barrage of animal images over

and over. So, maybe I was brainwashed by animals,
or maybe I came over it naturally. Whatever

the reason, I'm consumed by a desire to help
animals and care for them in any aspect. So

I even love seeing other people with their
animals and helping when I can. If you have

a question about your animal, please, feel
free, ask in the comments below.

Number two.
Yeah! Animals don't clean up after themselves.

Ah, more than half the time spent caring for
these animals is spent cleaning up after them,

like their poop and pee and ravaged toys and,
ah, other bodily fluids. [dramatic DUM DUM

DAAHHH music]
Yep.

Number three.
Logging is essential to knowing and caring

for your animals. It's priceless to be able
to go back three, four months, even years,

to see if you are dealing with an illness,
or you're managing a seasonal behavior, all

those things. You need to know that stuff.
For example, we have a bird named Oliver,

and he's a Sun Conure and he got really ill
about a year ago and we were worried that

he had this wasting disease that was really
contagious to other birds, and for the safety

of the rest of our flock we might have to
a necropsy which is the only way to determine

if that was the disease. A necropsy is an
autopsy except on an animal which means euthanasia.

I hated that idea so I wanted to see if there
was another option so I scoured all of his

backlogs, and I found out that he was sick.
About four years ago he got sick and he recovered

from that illness so it was unlikely that
he had that wasting disease, so we were able

to save his life because we did those logs.
So yeah, logging is like ingrained in my everyday

life. l could seriously tell you everything
that I ate today and every time me and my

sons went poo poo in the potty. Yeah, life
of the party!

Number four.
I love introducing all of my interns to the

basics of animal care. It's so fun seeing
them learn all these new skills and acquire

these basic life skills. The best part is
teaching them all to chop vegetables. It's

both hilarious and also really annoying. It
brings back all these memories of me trying

to learn how to do chopping veggies. It would
seriously take me like an hour or two every

other day to chop these vegetables and it
was, my hand would cramp up, and it was just

terrible, but, um, I just learned to pair
it with episodes of Buffy so, you know, it

wasn't so bad.
So even if my interns never take care of animals

again, or chop veggies for animals, at least
they have mad chopping skills, right? That's,
that's pretty cool.

And number five.
So I am so excited to be doing this channel,

because it has not only sparked my passion
to teach, but also to keep learning. There

is always room for improvement in everything
in life. So I promise to keep learning about

everything animal if you promise to keep asking
questions.

If you want to keep learning more about animals
and learning how we make caring for them possible,

then subscribe to Animal Wonders Montana and
join us on an adventure every week. If you

have a suggestion for an episode or any questions
at all, please ask them. You can find us on

our website, Twitter, Tumblr, Facebook...
links are below.
